elements.content: A series of new isostructural lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs), [Ln2(L)2­(DMAC)2]·​nH2O [Ln = La (1), Pr (2), Nd (3), Sm (4), Eu (5), Gd (6), Tb (7), and Tm (8); H4L = 5-(bis­(4-carboxy­benzyl)­amino)-isophthalic acid, DMAC = N,N′-dimethyl­acetamide], have been isolated. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that all complexes exhibit a rare (4,8)-connected alb-4,8-P topology with binuclear [Eu2­(COO)8] n secondary building units as 8-connected nodes and H4L ligands as 4-connected nodes. Two mixed-lanthanide analogues of single-lanthanide MOFs were designed and prepared [Ln = La0.93­Eu0.02­Tb0.05 (9) and Tm0.47­Eu0.18­Tb0.35 (10)] by way of careful regulation of the relative concentration of lanthanide ions which are able to emit pure white light. Luminescent sensing of complexes 3 and 5 has been investigated. Strikingly, complex 5 exhibits an excellent luminescent sensing to TNP with a high K sv value of 3.58 × 104 M–1 and a low detection limit of 4.66 × 10–4 mM. Complex 3 reveals high selectivity and sensitivity toward benzaldehyde (K sv of 4.9 × 104 M–1; detection limit of 3.4 × 10–4 mM). It represents the first example of an NIR luminescent MOF for sensing of benzaldehyde.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that all complexes exhibit a rare (4,8)-connected alb-4,8-P topology with binuclear [Eu2(COO)8] n  secondary building units as 8-connected nodes and H4L ligands as 4-connected nodes. elements.content: A series of new isostructural lanthanide metal−organic frameworks with unique (4,8)-connected alb-4,8-P topology perform highly pure white-light emission and detect TNP and benzaldehyde in the UV−visible and NIR regions with high selectivity and sensitivity.

elements.content: In a wide variety of MOFs-based functional materials, lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) are a fascinating category because of the unusual coordination modes, high coordination number, and connectivity of lanthanide ions, which could facilitate the formation of multidimensional networks with high thermal and chemical stability. Meanwhile, lanthanide ions as the metal component of Ln-MOFs are excellent candidates displaying luminescent properties due to their large Stokes shift, sharp emission, and high color purity. In particular, single-component white-light-emitting Ln-MOFs have attracted great interest owing to their advantages over multiple component systems such as greater reproducibility, low-cost preparation, ease of modification, and simpler fabrication processes. The white-light emission of MOFs is commonly generated from three pathways, including the luminescence of monochromatic, in situ doping of dichromatic and trichromatic. The treble emission pathway generally gives rise to finer color-rendering properties and higher luminescence quantum yields, thus gaining more popularity. However, exactly adjusting the ratio of multichromatic components to realize pure white-light emission with high quantum yield is still a great challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In a wide variety of MOFs-based functional materials, lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) are a fascinating category because of the unusual coordination modes, high coordination number, and connectivity of lanthanide ions, which could facilitate the formation of multidimensional networks with high thermal and chemical stability. Meanwhile, lanthanide ions as the metal component of Ln-MOFs are excellent candidates displaying luminescent properties due to their large Stokes shift, sharp emission, and high color purity. In particular, single-component white-light-emitting Ln-MOFs have attracted great interest owing to their advantages over multiple component systems such as greater reproducibility, low-cost preparation, ease of modification, and simpler fabrication processes. The white-light emission of MOFs is commonly generated from three pathways, including the luminescence of monochromatic, in situ doping of dichromatic and trichromatic. The treble emission pathway generally gives rise to finer color-rendering properties and higher luminescence quantum yields, thus gaining more popularity. However, exactly adjusting the ratio of multichromatic components to realize pure white-light emission with high quantum yield is still a great challenge.

elements.content: On the other hand, the unique photoluminescent properties and high recognition capability for guest molecules make Ln-MOFs a candidate for luminescent sensing, including the sensing of metal ions and small organic molecules, even the sensing of nitro explosives. For example, Li et al. reported a highly luminescent MOF [Zn2­(bpdc)2­(bpee)] (bpdc = 4,4′-biphenyl­dicarbox­ylate; bpee = 1,2-bipyridyl­ethene) for the detection of 2,4-DNT and DMNB with high sensitivity and reversible in 2009, which represents the first MOFs-based sensor for detecting nitro aromatic compounds (NACs). Notably, almost all the luminescence sensors occurred in the UV–visible region, seldom resulting from a response of near-infrared (NIR) luminescence, although the NIR emitting from Ln3+ ions has high permeability through biotissues and thus significantly improves deep-penetrating imaging and reduces photodamage. For the first time, Chen et al. report the first NIR luminescent MOF, Yb­(BPT)­(H2O)­(DMF)1.5­(H2O)1.25 (BPT = biphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarbox­ylate), for the highly selective and sensitive sensing of small molecules in 2011, which indicates the promise of this type of NIR luminescent materials for the sensing of substrates in biological systems.

For example, Li et al. reported a highly luminescent MOF [Zn2(bpdc)2(bpee)] (bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate; bpee = 1,2-bipyridylethene) for the detection of 2,4-DNT and DMNB with high sensitivity and reversible in 2009, which represents the first MOFs-based sensor for detecting nitro aromatic compounds (NACs). Notably, almost all the luminescence sensors occurred in the UV-visible region, seldom resulting from a response of near-infrared (NIR) luminescence, although the NIR emitting from Ln3+ ions has high permeability through biotissues and thus significantly improves deep-penetrating imaging and reduces photodamage. For the first time, Chen et al. report the first NIR luminescent MOF, Yb(BPT)(H2O)(DMF)1.5(H2O)1.25 (BPT = biphenyl-3,4',5-tricarboxylate), for the highly selective and sensitive sensing of small molecules in 2011, which indicates the promise of this type of NIR luminescent materials for the sensing of substrates in biological systems.

elements.content: We have been studying the structure and luminescence of lanthanide complexes for a long time. To design novel Ln-MOFs, realize pure white-light emission, and develop a new luminescent sensor of lanthanide MOF, an aromatic tetracarboxylate ligand 5-(bis­(4-carboxy­benzyl)­amino)-isophthalic acid was employed in the solvothermal reactions with La­(NO3)3·​6H2O. As a result, a series of isostructural 3D single-lanthanide MOFs [Ln2­(L)2­(DMAC)2]·​nH2O [Ln = La (1), Pr (2), Nd (3), Sm (4), Eu (5), Gd (6), Tb (7), and Tm (8); L = 5-(bis­(4-carboxy­benzyl)­amino)-isophthalic acid; DMAC = N,N′-dimethyl­acetamide] have been isolated. Two mixed-lanthanide analogues [Ln = La0.93­Eu0.02­Tb0.05 (9) and Tm0.47­Eu0.18­Tb0.35 (10)] were designed and prepared which emit pure white-light emission with impressive lifetime and quantum yield. In comparison with the previously reported result, luminescent sensing of complex 5 has been investigated, which exhibits the essential sensitivity for TNP with a high K sv value of 3.58 × 104 M–1 and a low detection limit of 4.66 × 10–4 mM, respectively. On the basis of high permeability through biotissues and thus significantly improves deep-penetrating imaging and reduces photodamage of the NIR emission of Ln3+ ions, complex 3 was employed as an NIR luminescent sensor detecting of benzaldehyde.

As a result, a series of isostructural 3D single-lanthanide MOFs [Ln2(L)2(DMAC)2]⋅nH2O [Ln = La (1), Pr (2), Nd (3), Sm (4), Eu (5), Gd (6), Tb (7), and Tm (8); L = 5-(bis(4-carboxybenzyl)amino)-isophthalic acid; DMAC = N,N'-dimethylacetamide] have been isolated. Two mixed-lanthanide analogues [Ln = La0.93Eu0.02Tb0.05 (9) and Tm0.47Eu0.18Tb0.35 (10)] were designed and prepared which emit pure white-light emission with impressive lifetime and quantum yield. In comparison with the previously reported result, luminescent sensing of complex 5 has been investigated, which exhibits the essential sensitivity for TNP with a high K sv value of 3.58 × 104 M-1 and a low detection limit of 4.66 × 10-4 mM, respectively. On the basis of high permeability through biotissues and thus significantly improves deep-penetrating imaging and reduces photodamage of the NIR emission of Ln3+ ions, complex 3 was employed as an NIR luminescent sensor detecting of benzaldehyde.

elements.content: Ln­(NO3)3·6H2O was obtained by the reactions of Ln2O3 and nitric acid. The H4L ligand and other chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without purification. 5-(Bis­(4-carboxy­benzyl)­amino)-isophthalic acid (H4L) was purchased from Jinan Henghua Sci. & Tec. Co. Ltd. (99%). All organic solvents and nitro compounds were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc. FT-IR spectra were collected on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 spectrophotometer by using KBr disks in the range of 4000–500 cm–1. UV spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrometer (in DMAC). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted on a PerkinElmer STA 6000 in the temperature range of 30–800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were performed on a Rigaku D/Max-3B X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα as the radiation source (λ = 0.15406 nm) in the angular range 2θ = 5–50° at room temperature. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were measured with an Edinburgh FLS 920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The steady-state near-infrared (NIR) emission spectrometer was equipped with a Hamamatsu R5509-72 supercooled photomultipliertube at 193 K and a TM 300 emission monochromator with NIR grating blazed at 1000 nm. The corrected spectra were obtained via a calibration curve supplied with the instrument. Luminescence lifetimes were recorded on a single photon counting spectrometer from Edinburgh Instrument (FLS 920) with a microsecond pulse lamp as the excitation. The absolute quantum yield was calculated using the following expression Φ = ∫ L emission ∫ E reference − ∫ E sample where L emission is the emission spectrum of the sample, collected using the sphere, E sample is the spectrum of the incidence light used to excite the sample, collected using the sphere, and E reference is the spectrum of the light used for excitation with only the reference in the sphere. The NIR luminescence quantum yield can be obtained by the ratio of the observed luminescence decay time τ and the radiative “natural” decay time τR of that specific Ln3+ ions. The Commission International de I′ Eclairage (CIE) color coordinates were calculated on the basis of the international CIE standards. The general CRI (color rendering index) were designated by the symbol Ra, which is the average value of R1 (5R) to R8 (10P). The numbers in parentheses indicate the Munsell color system. The CCT (correlated color temperature) values were obtained based on the corresponding CIE color coordinates.

Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentation

Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O was obtained by the reactions of Ln2O3 and nitric acid. The H4L ligand and other chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without purification. 5-(Bis(4-carboxybenzyl)amino)-isophthalic acid (H4L) was purchased from Jinan Henghua Sci. & Tec. Co. Ltd. (99%). All organic solvents and nitro compounds were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc. FT-IR spectra were collected on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 spectrophotometer by using KBr disks in the range of 4000-500 cm-1. UV spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrometer (in DMAC). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted on a PerkinElmer STA 6000 in the temperature range of 30-800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were performed on a Rigaku D/Max-3B X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα as the radiation source (λ = 0.15406 nm) in the angular range 2θ = 5-50° at room temperature. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were measured with an Edinburgh FLS 920 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The steady-state near-infrared (NIR) emission spectrometer was equipped with a Hamamatsu R5509-72 supercooled photomultipliertube at 193 K and a TM 300 emission monochromator with NIR grating blazed at 1000 nm. The corrected spectra were obtained via a calibration curve supplied with the instrument. Luminescence lifetimes were recorded on a single photon counting spectrometer from Edinburgh Instrument (FLS 920) with a microsecond pulse lamp as the excitation. The absolute quantum yield was calculated using the following expression 1    Φ =   ∫    L   emission      ∫    E   reference   -  ∫    E   sample        where L emission is the emission spectrum of the sample, collected using the sphere, E sample is the spectrum of the incidence light used to excite the sample, collected using the sphere, and E reference is the spectrum of the light used for excitation with only the reference in the sphere. The NIR luminescence quantum yield can be obtained by the ratio of the observed luminescence decay time τ and the radiative "natural" decay time τR of that specific Ln3+ ions. The Commission International de I' Eclairage (CIE) color coordinates were calculated on the basis of the international CIE standards. The general CRI (color rendering index) were designated by the symbol Ra, which is the average value of R1 (5R) to R8 (10P). The numbers in parentheses indicate the Munsell color system. The CCT (correlated color temperature) values were obtained based on the corresponding CIE color coordinates.

elements.content: Complexes 1–6 were synthesized by solvothermal reactions. A mixture of La­(NO3)3·​6H2O (0.25 mmol, 82 mg), H4L ligand (0.25 mmol, 112 mg), DMAC (3.5 mL), and water (1.5 mL) was added to a Teflon-lined autoclave at 100 °C for 2 days and then cooled to room temperature gradually. The resulting brown crystal was filtrated, and washed with DMAC for several times. The yield was 57, 55, 61, 49, 54, and 68% for 1–6 (based on H4L), respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Complexes 1-10 

Complexes 1-6 were synthesized by solvothermal reactions. A mixture of La(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.25 mmol, 82 mg), H4L ligand (0.25 mmol, 112 mg), DMAC (3.5 mL), and water (1.5 mL) was added to a Teflon-lined autoclave at 100 °C for 2 days and then cooled to room temperature gradually. The resulting brown crystal was filtrated, and washed with DMAC for several times. The yield was 57, 55, 61, 49, 54, and 68% for 1-6 (based on H4L), respectively.

Complexes 7 and 8 were synthesized by a room temperature reaction. A mixture of the corresponding lanthanide nitrate (0.3 mmol), H4L (0.3 mmol), DMAC (4 mL), and H2O (1.5 mL) was added to a round-bottom flask with a magneton, and stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The resulting white powder was filtrated, and washed with DMAC for several times. The yield was 72% and 65% for 7 and 8 (based on H4L), respectively. For the isostructure complexes 9 and 10, the synthetic methods are the same as the above-mentioned except using a lanthanide nitrate mixture as the starting materials in stoichiometric ratios. The yield was 61% and 67% for 9 and 10 (based on H4L), respectively. The identical structures of complexes 1–10 are demonstrated by the corresponding PXRD patterns (Figure S4).

elements.content: To obtain a stable suspension, the crystal samples of the complexes were finely ground and immersed in DMAC by ultrasonication treatment for 30 min. Then, they were made into a 0.2 mg/mL suspension. Finally, the stable suspensions were used for luminescence sensing measurement at room temperature. The excitation and emission slit widths were kept the same always.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Sensing Experiments

To obtain a stable suspension, the crystal samples of the complexes were finely ground and immersed in DMAC by ultrasonication treatment for 30 min. Then, they were made into a 0.2 mg/mL suspension. Finally, the stable suspensions were used for luminescence sensing measurement at room temperature. The excitation and emission slit widths were kept the same always.

elements.content: Crystal data for complexes 1–6 were collected on an Oxford Xcalibur Gemini Ultra diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Structures of complexes 1–6 were solved by using Patterson methods (SHELXS-97), expanded using Fourier methods, and refined using SHELXL-97 (full-matrix least-squares on F 2) and WinGX v1.70.01 programs packages. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Empirical absorption corrections based on equivalent reflections were applied. For complexes 1–3 and 5, the contributions of HIGHLY disordered anions/solvent molecules were treated as diffuse using the Squeeze procedure implemented in the PLATON program. The resulting new files were used to further refine the structures. The Squeeze results are consistent with TG and elemental analysis, which indicate that there is a water molecule in a structure unit as a free guest. These water molecules are added in the molecular formula. The crystal data and structure refinements of complexes 1–6 are summarized in . Crystallographic data for complexes 1–6 have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC Nos. 1509300–1509305.

X-ray Crystallographic Analysis

Crystal data for complexes 1-6 were collected on an Oxford Xcalibur Gemini Ultra diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Structures of complexes 1-6 were solved by using Patterson methods (SHELXS-97), expanded using Fourier methods, and refined using SHELXL-97 (full-matrix least-squares on F 2) and WinGX v1.70.01 programs packages. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Empirical absorption corrections based on equivalent reflections were applied. For complexes 1-3 and 5, the contributions of HIGHLY disordered anions/solvent molecules were treated as diffuse using the Squeeze procedure implemented in the PLATON program. The resulting new files were used to further refine the structures. The Squeeze results are consistent with TG and elemental analysis, which indicate that there is a water molecule in a structure unit as a free guest. These water molecules are added in the molecular formula. The crystal data and structure refinements of complexes 1-6 are summarized in . Crystallographic data for complexes 1-6 have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center with CCDC Nos. 1509300-1509305.

X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that complexes 1–6 are isostructural with P2/c space group. In a typical complex 5, each asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent Eu3+ ion, one deprotonated L4– ligand, and one coordinated DMAC molecule (Figure S5). Each Eu3+ ion is eight-coordinated by seven oxygen atoms from carboxyls of six H4L ligends and one oxygen atom from one DMAC molecule. Meanwhile, the neighboring Eu3+ ions were bridged through oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups of branched organic ligand and further form the [Eu2­(COO)8] n secondary building units (SBUs) (a). The neighboring dinuclear [Eu2­(COO)8] n units were connected by L4– in (k 1-k 1-μ2)-(k 1-k 1-μ2)-μ4 mode forming 1D chain (b). The adjacent 1D chains were linked by ligand L4– in (k 1-k 1-μ2)-(k 1-k 1-μ1)-μ3 mode, forming a 2D network (c). Furthermore, the adjacent networks further accumulate into 3D frameworks in the vertical direction (d). In the past report, the H4L ligands have been used as a 4-connected node, and combined with the 4-connected [In­(COO)4] group building zeolitic metal–organic frameworks (ZMOFs) with a SOD topology. In this work, the dinuclear [Eu2­(COO)8] n SBUs connected by eight carboxylate groups can be considered as an 8-connected node. As a result, the framework can be viewed as a (4,8)-connected 3D framework with a topological point symbol of {44·​62}2​{48·​617·​83} (e). Such a topology is usually associated with high connectivity and long intermodal bridges. PLATON calculation shows that there is about 26% accessible volume of the unit cell volume when the guest molecules were removed.

Results and Disussion

Crystal Structure

X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that complexes 1-6 are isostructural with P2/c space group. In a typical complex 5, each asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent Eu3+ ion, one deprotonated L4- ligand, and one coordinated DMAC molecule (Figure S5). Each Eu3+ ion is eight-coordinated by seven oxygen atoms from carboxyls of six H4L ligends and one oxygen atom from one DMAC molecule. Meanwhile, the neighboring Eu3+ ions were bridged through oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups of branched organic ligand and further form the [Eu2(COO)8] n  secondary building units (SBUs) (a). The neighboring dinuclear [Eu2(COO)8] n  units were connected by L4- in (k 1-k 1-μ2)-(k 1-k 1-μ2)-μ4 mode forming 1D chain (b). The adjacent 1D chains were linked by ligand L4- in (k 1-k 1-μ2)-(k 1-k 1-μ1)-μ3 mode, forming a 2D network (c). Furthermore, the adjacent networks further accumulate into 3D frameworks in the vertical direction (d). In the past report, the H4L ligands have been used as a 4-connected node, and combined with the 4-connected [In(COO)4] group building zeolitic metal-organic frameworks (ZMOFs) with a SOD topology. In this work, the dinuclear [Eu2(COO)8] n  SBUs connected by eight carboxylate groups can be considered as an 8-connected node. As a result, the framework can be viewed as a (4,8)-connected 3D framework with a topological point symbol of {44⋅62}2{48⋅617⋅83} (e). Such a topology is usually associated with high connectivity and long intermodal bridges. PLATON calculation shows that there is about 26% accessible volume of the unit cell volume when the guest molecules were removed.

elements.content: Photoluminescent spectra for all single-lanthanide complexes 1–8 were conducted in solid state at room temperature ( and S6–S10). Complexes 1 and 8 exhibit lanthanide ion tuned ligand-centered emission at 426 and 421 nm under excitation at 398 and 394 nm, respectively. Complex 4 exhibits co-luminescence of the Sm3+ ion and the ligand excited at 417 nm, implying that the H4L ligand can only partly sensitize the Sm3+ ion. Complex 5 exhibits an intense characteristic red emission of Eu3+ with peaks located at 590, 614, 648, and 698 nm upon being excited at 398 nm, respectively, which are attributed to the 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1–4) transitions of the Eu3+ ion (b). The lifetime and quantum yield of complex 5 are τ1 = 0.26 ms (4.67%), τ2 = 1.10 ms (95.33%), and Φ = 21.78%. In contrast, complex 2 reveals the NIR luminescence around 1020 and 1227 nm when excited at 420 nm, which are attributed to f–f transitions of 1D2 → 3F4 and 1G4 → 3H4 for the Pr3+ ion, respectively (Figure S7). Complex 3 exhibits the characteristic NIR luminescence around 890, 1054, and 1326 nm under excitation at 386 nm that can be attributed to the 4F3/2 → 4F9/2, 4F3/2 → 4F11/2, and 4F3/2 → 4F13/2 transitions of the Nd3+ ion, respectively (Figure S8). The lifetime and quantum yield are τ1 = 2.11 μs (41.83%), τ2 = 7.51 μs (58.17%), and Φ = 1.9%. Notably, the lifetimes and yields of complexes 3 and 5 are comparable to those of the reported neodymium and europium complexes ().

In contrast, complex 2 reveals the NIR luminescence around 1020 and 1227 nm when excited at 420 nm, which are attributed to f-f transitions of 1D2 → 3F4 and 1G4 → 3H4 for the Pr3+ ion, respectively (Figure S7). Complex 3 exhibits the characteristic NIR luminescence around 890, 1054, and 1326 nm under excitation at 386 nm that can be attributed to the 4F3/2 → 4F9/2, 4F3/2 → 4F11/2, and 4F3/2 → 4F13/2 transitions of the Nd3+ ion, respectively (Figure S8). The lifetime and quantum yield are τ1 = 2.11 μs (41.83%), τ2 = 7.51 μs (58.17%), and Φ = 1.9%. In view of that complexes 1–8 are isostructural and complexes 1 and 8 exhibit intense blue emission (a,d), it will, therefore, be possible to construct white-light-emitting materials by doping of both Eu3+ ions and Tb3+ ions into the host frameworks of complexes 1 or 8 with an appropriate molar ratio. In fact, the designed mixed-lanthanide complexes 9 and 10 have realized the white-light emission when excited at 320 and 322 nm (). The optimal concentrations of the components are 93 mol % for La3+ ions, 2 mol % for Eu3+ ions, and 5 mol % ions for Tb3+ ions in complex 9, and 47 mol % for Tm3+ ions, 18 mol % for Eu3+ ions, and 35 mol % for Tb3+ ions in complex 10. The CIE coordinates (0.329, 0.333) and (0.331, 0.336) for complexes 9 and 10, respectively, fall within the white-light region of the 1931 CIE chromaticity diagram. The quantum yield Φoverall is 15.3% for complex 9 and 13.9% for complex 10. The lifetimes are τTb = 785 μs (monitored at 542 nm) and τEu = 436 μs (monitored at 614 nm) for complex 9, τTb = 705 μs (monitored at 542 nm) and τEu = 405 μs (monitored at 614 nm) for complex 10, respectively (Figures S12 and S13). The CRI index (80.2 and 78.7) and CCT value (5652 and 5558 K) could also be readily realized for complexes 9 and 10. Notably, the quantum yield of complex 9 is slightly higher than that of complex 10, attributed to the poor sensitivity of the ligand to the Tm3+ ion. In comparison with the quantum yields with previously reported three-component analogues (), the quantum yields of complexes 9 and 10 are higher than those of La0.6­Eu0.1­Tb0.3CPOMBA (H3CP­OMBA = 4,4′-(((5-carboxy-1,3-phenyl­ene)­bis­(oxy))­bis­(methylene)), [Sm41.26­Gd44.72­Eu14.02­(4-SBA)­(IP)­OH] and [Sm27.93­Tb53.13­Eu18.94­(4-SBA)­(IP)­OH] (4-SBA = 4-sulfo­benzoate and IP = 1H-imidazo­[4,5-f]­[1,10]-phenanthroline), but lower than those of La0.6­Eu0.1­Tb0.3-BTPCA (H3­BTPCA = (1,1′,1-(benzene-1,3,5-triyl)­tripiperi­dine-4-carboxylic acid) and [H2­NMe2]3­[Gd1–x–y ­Eu x Tb y ­(L)3] (L = pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid).

elements.content: The efficient energy transfer from ligands to Eu3+ ions encourages us to investigate the luminescent sensing capacity of complex 5. To obtain a stable suspension, the crystal samples of complex 5 were finely ground and immersed in DMAC by ultrasonication treatment for 30 min. Then, the luminescent intensity of the suspension was investigated by addition of various nitro aromatic compounds, including NB, m-DNB, 2,4-DNT, 2,6-DNT, and TNP, in DMAC solution (10 mM). As a result, the maximum luminescent intensity of complex 5 was reduced by 22.27, 25.88, 28.03, 28.78, and 75.08%, respectively, when the content of nitro aromatic compounds is 120 μL (10 mM, in DMAC solution) (a). It suggests that the quenching efficiencies of complex 5 follow the sequence of TNP > 2,6-DNT > 2,4-DNT > NB > m-DNB (b).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Sensing

The efficient energy transfer from ligands to Eu3+ ions encourages us to investigate the luminescent sensing capacity of complex 5. To obtain a stable suspension, the crystal samples of complex 5 were finely ground and immersed in DMAC by ultrasonication treatment for 30 min. Then, the luminescent intensity of the suspension was investigated by addition of various nitro aromatic compounds, including NB, m-DNB, 2,4-DNT, 2,6-DNT, and TNP, in DMAC solution (10 mM). As a result, the maximum luminescent intensity of complex 5 was reduced by 22.27, 25.88, 28.03, 28.78, and 75.08%, respectively, when the content of nitro aromatic compounds is 120 μL (10 mM, in DMAC solution) (a). It suggests that the quenching efficiencies of complex 5 follow the sequence of TNP > 2,6-DNT > 2,4-DNT > NB > m-DNB (b).

elements.content: (a) Quenching efficiency of complex 5 for various nitro aromatic compounds. (b) The relationships between emission intensities and nitro aromatic compounds. (c) Emission spectra of complex 5 dispersed in DMAC upon incremental addition of TNP solution in DMAC. (d) Reproducibility of complex 5 dispersed in DMAC with TNP solution of 120 μL.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Quenching efficiency of complex 5 for various nitro aromatic compounds. (b) The relationships between emission intensities and nitro aromatic compounds. (c) Emission spectra of complex 5 dispersed in DMAC upon incremental addition of TNP solution in DMAC. (d) Reproducibility of complex 5 dispersed in DMAC with TNP solution of 120 μL.

elements.content: The quenching efficiency can be quantitatively explained by the Stern–Volmer (SV) equation: I/I 0 = K sv[Q] + 1, where I and I 0 are the luminescent intensities of the suspension of complex 5 before and after for sensing nitro aromatic compounds, [Q] is the molar concentration of analytes (M–1), and K sv is the Stern–Volmer constant. In this work, the SV plots for all analytes are nearly linear in the range of low concentrations; the K sv can then be estimated as 1.39 × 103 M–1 for NB, 1.9 × 103 M–1 for m-DNB, 2.33 × 103 M–1 for 2,4-DNT, 2.4 × 103 M–1 for 2,6-DNT, and 3.58 × 104 M–1 for TNP, respectively (Figures S15–S19). Particularly, the K sv value of complex 5 is comparable to that of most of the MOF-based probes toward TNP reported recently (Table S3). On the basis of K sv values and the standard deviations for five repeated luminescent measurements of blank solutions, the detection limits (3σ/K sv) of complex 5 toward five nitro aromatic compounds are also calculated (Table S1). For complex 5, TNP is the most efficient quencher with a detection limit of 4.66 × 10–4 mM. The high quenching constant and low detection limits indicate that complex 5 exhibits extremely high detection sensitivity toward TNP (). In addition, complex 5 can be recycled by centrifuging the suspension after use and washing several times with DMAC; the luminescent intensity and quenching ability of complex 5 exhibited negligible changes after being used for four repeated cycles (d). The identical structure of the regenerative sample is demonstrated by the corresponding PXRD patterns (Figure S20). Similarly, The H4L ligand was also employed as a luminescent sensor toward the detection of TNP in DMAC. The emission spectra of H4L dispersed in DMAC were investigated upon incremental addition of TNP contents. The K sv value of the H4L ligand is 2.9 × 104 M–1 for TNP, which is smaller than 3.58 × 104 M–1 of complex 5 (). This indicated that the framework of complex 5 is more efficient than the H4L ligand for the detecting of TNP, which may be attributed to the presence of pores in the framework to facilitate possible host–guest interactions.

In order to better understand the luminescent quenching effect of complex 5 toward nitro aromatic compounds, the quenching mechanism was analyzed. Generally, the conduction band (CB) of a MOF lies at a higher energy than the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) energy of nitro aromatic compounds, and leads to a luminescent quenching. When the LUMOs energy gets lower, the electron accepting efficiency of the nitro aromatic compounds and luminescent quenching become higher. It was found that the LUMOs energies are in good agreement with the maximum quenching efficiency observed for TNP; however, the order of observed quenching efficiency is not fully in accordance with the LUMOs energies of other nitro aromatic compounds (Figure S21 and Table S2). The results indicate that there may be another luminescent quenching mechanism in this work, such as fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET).

When the LUMOs energy gets lower, the electron accepting efficiency of the nitro aromatic compounds and luminescent quenching become higher. It was found that the LUMOs energies are in good agreement with the maximum quenching efficiency observed for TNP; however, the order of observed quenching efficiency is not fully in accordance with the LUMOs energies of other nitro aromatic compounds (Figure S21 and Table S2). elements.content: In comparison with UV–visible luminescent sensing, an NIR luminescent sensor is scarce. In view of the excellent sensitization effect of the H4L ligand on the Nd3+ ion, complex 3 was employed for the sensing of small organic molecules. As shows in a and S22, the NIR light-emitting intensity largely depends on the type of solvents, particularly in the case of benzaldehyde. It exhibits the most significant quenching effects. The sensing properties of complex 3 toward benzaldehyde were further investigated by monitoring a series of emissions of complex 3 in DMAC with gradually increased benzaldehyde content. As predicted, the luminescent intensity of the suspended solution of complex 3 in DMAC gradually decreases with increasing content of benzaldehyde. At a content of 200 μL (10 mM), the luminescence intensity is nearly completely quenched with a high quenching efficiency of about 94% (b). Similarly, the K sv constant is estimated to be 4.9 × 104 M–1 (b) and the detection limit of complex 3 toward benzaldehyde is estimated to be 3.4 × 10–4 mM. To the best of our knowledge, it is the first example that the luminescence MOFs were applied for benzaldehyde detection with a high K sv and low detection limit. Previously, only {[Sm2Zn­(abtc)2­(H2O)4]·​2H2O} (abtc = 3,3′,5,5′-azo-benzene­tetra­carboxylic acid) was documented for detecting benzaldehyde with a K sv value of 1.36 × 104 M–1.

elements.content: To further explore the mechanism of the luminescence quenching to benzaldehyde, some necessary measures are performed. First, the PXRD spectrum of the complex 3 before and after benzaldehyde treatment verifies that the framework of complex 3 remained intact. Therefore, the luminescence quenching was not caused by alteration of the crystallization structure (Figure S23). Second, according to the static quenching mechanism, the static quenching does not change the lifetime. In contrast, the dynamic quenching will cause a comparable decrease in lifetime. The emission lifetime of complex 3 in the absence and presence of benzaldehyde was measured and remained almost unchanged in the average lifetime (Figure S24), implying that there are no interactions between the Nd3+ ions and benzaldehyde. Thus, the quenching in the emission intensity is supposed to be the interactions between benzaldehyde and the other sections of frameworks, such as ligands. Finally, the FT-IR spectra of complex 3 before and after treatment with benzaldehyde (Figure S25) reveal that the peak belonging to the skeleton vibration of ligands’ benzene rings shifted from 796 to 782 cm–1, which suggests that strong hydrogen bonds interactions exist between the framework and benzaldehyde. Therefore, we speculate that the hydrogen bonds between benzaldehyde and frameworks affect the energy transfer efficiency from the ligands to Nd3+ ions, which leads to a luminescent quenching.

elements.content: Isolation of a series of isostructural lanthanide metal–organic frameworks 1–8 demonstrates that 5-(bis­(4-carboxy­benzyl)­amino)-isophthalic acid is able to react with Ln­(NO3)3·​6H2O, forming Ln-MOFs with a unique (4,8)-connected alb-4,8-P topology in solvothermal conditions. When Eu3+ ions and Tb3+ ions were doped into the isostructural complexes 1 and 8, the highly pure white-light emission was realized. This lays the foundation for the subsequent fabrication of nanostructure materials and light-emitting devices. In addition, the characteristic luminescence of Nd3+ and Eu3+ ions in complexes 3 and 5 suggests that the energy transfer between the ligand and lanthanide ions is effective. The typical luminescence of Eu3+ ions in complex 5 could be quenched efficiently by trace amounts of TNP, which could be employed as a luminescence sensor for TNP with high selectivity, sensitivity, and reproducibility. The characteristic NIR luminescence of complex 3 shows solvent-dependent changes with a significant quenching effect toward benzaldehyde. It represents the first NIR luminescent sensor for detecting benzaldehyde. This approach may provide potential materials for WLED and luminescent sensing application.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Isolation of a series of isostructural lanthanide metal-organic frameworks 1-8 demonstrates that 5-(bis(4-carboxybenzyl)amino)-isophthalic acid is able to react with Ln(NO3)3⋅6H2O, forming Ln-MOFs with a unique (4,8)-connected alb-4,8-P topology in solvothermal conditions. When Eu3+ ions and Tb3+ ions were doped into the isostructural complexes 1 and 8, the highly pure white-light emission was realized. This lays the foundation for the subsequent fabrication of nanostructure materials and light-emitting devices. In addition, the characteristic luminescence of Nd3+ and Eu3+ ions in complexes 3 and 5 suggests that the energy transfer between the ligand and lanthanide ions is effective. The typical luminescence of Eu3+ ions in complex 5 could be quenched efficiently by trace amounts of TNP, which could be employed as a luminescence sensor for TNP with high selectivity, sensitivity, and reproducibility. The characteristic NIR luminescence of complex 3 shows solvent-dependent changes with a significant quenching effect toward benzaldehyde. It represents the first NIR luminescent sensor for detecting benzaldehyde. This approach may provide potential materials for WLED and luminescent sensing application.

cln_elements.content:
Complexes 1–6 were synthesized by solvothermal reactions. A mixture of La­(NO3)3·​6H2O (0.25 mmol, 82 mg), H4L ligand (0.25 mmol, 112 mg), DMAC (3.5 mL), and water (1.5 mL) was added to a Teflon-lined autoclave at 100 °C for 2 days and then cooled to room temperature gradually. The resulting brown crystal was filtrated, and washed with DMAC for several times. The yield was 57, 55, 61, 49, 54, and 68% for 1–6 (based on H4L), respectively.

Complexes 7 and 8 were synthesized by a room temperature reaction. A mixture of the corresponding lanthanide nitrate (0.3 mmol), H4L (0.3 mmol), DMAC (4 mL), and H2O (1.5 mL) was added to a round-bottom flask with a magneton, and stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The resulting white powder was filtrated, and washed with DMAC for several times. The yield was 72% and 65% for 7 and 8 (based on H4L), respectively. For the isostructure complexes 9 and 10, the synthetic methods are the same as the above-mentioned except using a lanthanide nitrate mixture as the starting materials in stoichiometric ratios. The yield was 61% and 67% for 9 and 10 (based on H4L), respectively. The identical structures of complexes 1–10 are demonstrated by the corresponding PXRD patterns (Figure S4).

A mixture of La(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.25 mmol, 82 mg), H4L ligand (0.25 mmol, 112 mg), DMAC (3.5 mL), and water (1.5 mL) was added to a Teflon-lined autoclave at 100 °C for 2 days and then cooled to room temperature gradually. The resulting brown crystal was filtrated, and washed with DMAC for several times. The yield was 57, 55, 61, 49, 54, and 68% for 1-6 (based on H4L), respectively.

Complexes 7 and 8 were synthesized by a room temperature reaction. A mixture of the corresponding lanthanide nitrate (0.3 mmol), H4L (0.3 mmol), DMAC (4 mL), and H2O (1.5 mL) was added to a round-bottom flask with a magneton, and stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The resulting white powder was filtrated, and washed with DMAC for several times. The yield was 72% and 65% for 7 and 8 (based on H4L), respectively. For the isostructure complexes 9 and 10, the synthetic methods are the same as the above-mentioned except using a lanthanide nitrate mixture as the starting materials in stoichiometric ratios. Luminescence

Photoluminescent spectra for all single-lanthanide complexes 1–8 were conducted in solid state at room temperature ( and S6–S10). Complexes 1 and 8 exhibit lanthanide ion tuned ligand-centered emission at 426 and 421 nm under excitation at 398 and 394 nm, respectively. Complex 4 exhibits co-luminescence of the Sm3+ ion and the ligand excited at 417 nm, implying that the H4L ligand can only partly sensitize the Sm3+ ion. Complex 5 exhibits an intense characteristic red emission of Eu3+ with peaks located at 590, 614, 648, and 698 nm upon being excited at 398 nm, respectively, which are attributed to the 5D0 → 7F J (J = 1–4) transitions of the Eu3+ ion (b). The lifetime and quantum yield of complex 5 are τ1 = 0.26 ms (4.67%), τ2 = 1.10 ms (95.33%), and Φ = 21.78%. In contrast, complex 2 reveals the NIR luminescence around 1020 and 1227 nm when excited at 420 nm, which are attributed to f–f transitions of 1D2 → 3F4 and 1G4 → 3H4 for the Pr3+ ion, respectively (Figure S7). Complex 3 exhibits the characteristic NIR luminescence around 890, 1054, and 1326 nm under excitation at 386 nm that can be attributed to the 4F3/2 → 4F9/2, 4F3/2 → 4F11/2, and 4F3/2 → 4F13/2 transitions of the Nd3+ ion, respectively (Figure S8). The lifetime and quantum yield are τ1 = 2.11 μs (41.83%), τ2 = 7.51 μs (58.17%), and Φ = 1.9%. Notably, the lifetimes and yields of complexes 3 and 5 are comparable to those of the reported neodymium and europium complexes ().
